statement.p: Consider a function f(x) whose third order Maclaurin polynomial is 4 + 3x^2 + \frac{1}{2}x^3. What is f'(0)? What is f''(0)?

hint.p: Compare the given polynomial to the definition of a Maclaurin polynomial.

solution.p:
The third Maclaurin polynomial for f(x) is
f(0) + f'(0)x +\frac{f''(0)}{2}\cdot x^2 + \frac{f'''(0)}{6}\cdot x^3 &=4+3x^2+\frac{1}{2}x^3.
The coefficient of x is f'(0) on one side, and 0 on the other, so f'(0)=0.
The coefficient of x^2 is \dfrac{1}{2}f''(0) on one side, and 3 on the other, so f''(0)=6.

statement.p: Consider a function h(x) whose third order Maclaurin polynomial is 1+4x-\dfrac{1}{3}x^2 + \dfrac{2}{3}x^3. What is h^{(3)}(0)?

solution.p:
The third Maclaurin polynomial for h(x) is
h(0) + h'(0)x +\frac{h''(0)}{2}\cdot x^2 + \frac{h^{(3)}(0)}{3!}\cdot x^3 &= 1+4x-\frac{1}{3}x^2 + \frac{2}{3}x^3
The coefficient of x^3 is \dfrac{1}{3!}h^{(3)}(0) on one side, and \dfrac{2}{3} on the other. Thus \dfrac{h^{(3)}(0)}{6}=\dfrac{2}{3}, so h^{(3)}(0)=6\cdot\dfrac{2}{3} = 4.

statement.p: The third order Taylor polynomial of h(x) about x=2 is 3 + \dfrac{1}{2}(x-2) + 2(x-2)^3.
What is h'(2)? What is h''(2)?

hint.p: Compare the given polynomial to the definition of a Taylor polynomial.

solution.p:
The third order Taylor polynomial for h(x) about x=2 is
h(2) + h'(2)(x-2) +\frac{h''(2)}{2}\cdot (x-2)^2 + \frac{h'''(2)}{6}\cdot (x-2)^3
The coefficient of (x-2) is h'(2) in the definition, and \dfrac{1}{2} in the given function, so h'(2)=\dfrac{1}{2}.
The coefficient of (x-2)^2 is \dfrac{1}{2}h''(2) in the definition, and 0 in the given function, so h'(2)=0.

statement.p:
The function f(x) has the property that f(3)=2,\ f'(3)=4 and f''(3)=-10.
Use the linear approximation to f(x) centred at x=3 to approximate f(2.98).
Use the quadratic approximation to f(x) centred at x=3 to approximate f(2.98).

ol.label: a
ol.li:
For x near 3,
f(x)\approx f(3)+f'(3)(x-3)=2+4(x-3)
In particular
f(2.98)\approx 2+4(2.98-3)=2-0.08=1.92

statement.p: Use the tangent line to the graph of y = x^{1/3} at x = 8 to find an approximate value for 10^{1/3}. Is the approximation too large or too small?

hint.p: You can use the error formula to determine whether the approximation is too large or too small.

solution.p:
The tangent line approximation to 10^{1/3} is
g(10)&\approx g(8)+g'(8)(10-8)
&=2+\dfrac{1}{12}(2)=\dfrac{13}{6}
Using the error formula: g(10)&=g(8)+g'(8)(10-8)+\half g''(c)(10-8)^2
for some 8 \lt c \lt 10. Since g''(c)=-\dfrac{2}{9c^{5/3}}, g''(c) is negative, so g(10) is \dfrac{13}{6} plus some negative quantity. So, the tangent line approximation is too big.

statement.p: Estimate \sqrt{2} using a linear approximation.

solution.p:
We use the function f(x)=\sqrt{x} and point a=1 as the centre of our approximation, since we can easily calculate
f(a)&=f(1)=\sqrt{1}=1.
We compute f'(x)=\dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}, so
f'(1)&=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{1}}=\frac{1}{2}.
So, a linear approximation of \sqrt{2}=f(2) is
\sqrt{2}&\approx T_1(2)= f(1) + f'(1)\cdot (2-1)
&=1+\frac{1}{2}=\frac{3}{2}.

statement.p: Estimate \sqrt[3]{26} using a linear approximation.

hint.p: Use the function f(x)=x^{1/3}. What is a good choice of centre?

solution.p:
We use the function f(x)=x^{1/3} and point a=27 as the centre of our approximation since we can easily compute
f(27)&=3
We compute f'(x)=\dfrac{1}{3} x^{-2/3}, so
f'(27)&= \frac{1}{3} \cdot (27)^{-2/3} = \frac{1}{27}
So, the linear approximation of 26^{1/3} = f(26) is
26^{1/3}&\approx T_1\left(26\right) = f(27) + f'(27)\cdot (26-27)
&= 3 - \frac{1}{27} = \frac{80}{27}

statement.p: Estimate (10.1)^5 using a linear approximation.

solution.p: We use the function f(x)=x^5 and point a=10 as the centre of our approximation since we know that f(a)=f(10)=10^5.
Since f'(x) = 5x^4 we have f'(10) = 50,000.

statement.p: Estimate \sin\left(\dfrac{101\pi}{100}\right) using a linear approximation. (Leave your answer in terms of \pi.)

hint.p: If you use the function f(x)=\sin(x), what is a good centre?

solution.p:
We use the function f(x)=\sin(x) and point a=\pi as the centre of our approximation since we know that
\sin(a)&=f(\pi)=\sin{\pi}=0.
and \pi is reasonably close to \dfrac{101\pi}{100}. We compute f'(x)=\cos(x), so
f'(\pi)&=\cos(\pi) = -1.
So, the linear approximation of \sin\left(\frac{101\pi}{100}\right) is f\left(\frac{101\pi}{100}\right)&\approx T_1\left(\frac{101\pi}{100}\right)
&= f(\pi) + f'(\pi)\cdot \left(\frac{101\pi}{100}-\pi\right)
&=0+(-1)\cdot\frac{\pi}{100}=-\frac{\pi}{100}.

statement.p: Use a linear approximation to estimate \arctan(1.1), using \arctan 1 = \dfrac{\pi}{4}.
Use a linear approximation to estimate (2.001)^3. Write your answer in the form n/1000 where n is an integer.

solution.p: Set f(x)=(2+x)^3, so we are approximating f(0.001). The obvious choice of a is a=0.
Remark: if we had chosen f(x)=x^3 and a=2, the result would have been exactly the same.

statement.p: Using a suitable linear approximation, estimate (8.06)^{2/3}. Give your answer as a fraction in which both the numerator and denominator are integers.

hint.p: You can try using f(x)=(8+x)^{1/3}. What is a suitable centre for your approximation?

statement.p: Find the third--order Taylor polynomial for f(x)=(1 - 3x)^{-1/3} around x = 0.

hint.p: This is the same as the Maclaurin polynomial.

solution.p:
We begin by finding the derivatives of f at x=0.
f(x)&=(1 - 3x)^{-1/3} & f(0) & = 1
f'(x)&=(-3)\frac{-1}{3}(1 - 3x)^{-4/3}=(1-3x)^{-4/3} & f'(0) & = 1
f''(x)&=(-3)\frac{-4}{3}(1-3x)^{-7/3}={4}(1 - 3x)^{-7/3} & f''(0) & = 4
f^{(3)}(x)&=(-3)(4)\frac{-7}{3}(1-3x)^{-10/3}=28(1 - 3x)^{-10/3} & f^{(3)}(0) & = 28
Plugging these into the definition of a Taylor Polynomial, we find that the third--order Taylor polynomial for f around x = 0 is
T_3(x)&=1+x+\frac{4}{2!}x^2+\frac{28}{3!}x^3
&=1 + x +2x^2+\frac{14}{3}x^3

statement.p: Consider a function f(x) which has f^{(3)}(x)=\dfrac{x}{22-x^2}. Show that when we approximate f(2) using its second order Taylor polynomial at a=1, the absolute value of the error is less than \frac{1}{50}=0.02.

hint.p: This is a straightforward application of Equation.

ul.li:
By Equation, the absolute value of the error is
\left|\frac{f'''(c)}{3!}\cdot (2-1)^3\right| = \left|\frac{c}{6(22-c^2)}\right| for some c \in (1,2).

Alternatively, notice that c is an increasing function of c, while 22-c^2 is a decreasing function of c. Hence the fraction is an increasing function of c and takes its largest value at c=2. Hence
\left|\frac{c}{6(22-c^2)}\right| & \leq \frac{2}{6\times 18} = \frac{1}{54} \leq \frac{1}{50}.

statement.p: Consider a function f(x) which has f^{(4)}(x)=\dfrac{\cos(x^2)}{3-x}. Show that when we approximate f(0.5) using its third order Maclaurin polynomial, the absolute value of the error is less than \frac{1}{500}=0.002.

ul.li: For any c we have |\cos(c^2)| \leq 1, and for c \lt 0.5 we have 3-c \gt 2.5, so that \left|\frac{\cos(c^2)}{3-c}\right| \leq \frac{1}{2.5}\,.
For any c we have |\cos(c^2)| \leq 1, and for c \lt 0.5 we have 3-c \gt 2.5, so that \left|\frac{\cos(c^2)}{3-c}\right| \leq \frac{1}{2.5}\,.

statement.p: Consider a function f(x) which has f^{(3)}(x)=\dfrac{e^{-x}}{8+x^2}. Show that when we approximate f(1) using its second order Maclaurin polynomial, the absolute value of the error is less than 1/40.

ul.li:
By Equation, there is c\in(0,1) such that the error is
\left|\frac{f'''(c)}{3!}\cdot (1-0)^3\right| &= \left|\frac{e^{-c}}{6(8+c^2)}\right|.

By Equation, there is c\in(0,1) such that the error is
\left|\frac{f'''(c)}{3!}\cdot (1-0)^3\right| &= \left|\frac{e^{-c}}{6(8+c^2)}\right|.

Alternatively, notice that e^{-c} is a decreasing function of c, while for 0 \lt c 8+c^2 is an increasing function of c. Hence the fraction is a decreasing function of c and takes its largest value at c=0. Hence
\left|\frac{e^c}{6(8+c^2)}\right| & \leq \frac{1}{6\times 8} = \frac{1}{48} \lt \frac{1}{40}.

ol.label: a
ol.li: By using an appropriate linear approximation for f(x)=x^{1/3}, estimate 5^{2/3}.
Improve your answer in by making a quadratic approximation.
Obtain an error estimate for your answer in (not just by comparing with your calculator's answer for 5^{2/3}).

solution.p:
To obtain an error estimate for the linear approximation, we use that
5^{2/3}=f(25)= f(27)+f'(27)(25-27)+\frac{1}{2} f''(z)(25-27)^2
for some z between 25 and 27. The error is exactly
\left|\frac{1}{2} f''(z)(25-27)^2\right| =\left|\frac{1}{2} \left(-\frac{2}{9}x^{-5/3}\right)(-2)^2\right| =\frac{4}{9}z^{-5/3}. For z between 25 and 27, z^{-5/3} is between 25^{-5/3} and 27^{-5/3}. The biggest this can be is 25^{-5/3}, so the maximum possible error is {\dfrac{4}{9}25^{-5/3}}.
To get a better idea of what this number is, we note 2.9^3 \lt 25, so \frac{4}{9}25^{-5/3} \lt \frac{4}{9}2.9^{-5}=0.0022.

statement.p:
The 4th order Maclaurin polynomial for f(x) is
T_4(x)=5x^2-9
What is the third order Maclaurin polynomial for f(x)?

hint.p:
The fourth order Maclaurin polynomial for f(x) is
T_4(x)&=f(0)+f'(0)x+\frac{1}{2}f''(0)x^2+\frac{1}{3!}f'''(0)x^3+\frac{1}{4!}f^{(4)}(0)x^4
while the third order Maclaurin polynomial for f(x) is T_3(x)&=f(0)+f'(0)x+\frac{1}{2}f''(0)x^2+\frac{1}{3!}f'''(0)x^3

solution.p:
The fourth order Maclaurin polynomial for f(x) is
T_4(x)&=f(0)+f'(0)x+\frac{1}{2}f''(0)x^2+\frac{1}{3!}f'''(0)x^3+\frac{1}{4!}f^{(4)}(0)x^4
while the third order Maclaurin polynomial for f(x) is T_3(x)&=f(0)+f'(0)x+\frac{1}{2}f''(0)x^2+\frac{1}{3!}f'''(0)x^3
So, we simply chop off the part of T_4(x) that includes x^4. Since that's already 0, in this case T_3(x)=T_4(x). T_3(x)&=5x^2-9

statement.p:
The equation y^4+xy=x^2-1 defines y implicitly as a function of x near the point x=2,\ y=1.
Use the tangent line approximation at the given point to estimate the value of y when x=2.1.
Use the quadratic approximation at the given point to estimate the value of y when x=2.1.
Make a sketch showing how the curve relates to the tangent line at the given point.

hint.p: For part, think about what the quadratic approximation looks like is it pointing up or down?

solution.p:
y is a function of x that obeys
y(x)^4+xy(x)&=x^2-1
By implicit differentiation (and then subbing in x=2, y(2)=1) 4y(x)^3y'(x)+y(x)+xy'(x)&=2x
4y'(2)+1+2y'(2)&=4
y'(2)&=\frac{1}{2}
Differentiating with respect to x a second time and then subbing in x=2, y(2)=1, y'(2)=\frac{1}{2}:
12y(x)^2y'(x)^2+4y(x)^3y''(x)+y'(x)+y'(x)+xy''(x)&=2
12\times1\times\frac{1}{4}+4y''(2)+\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}+2y''(2)&=2 6y''(2)&=-2
y''(2)&=-\frac{1}{3}
The tangent line approximation to y(x) at x=2 is
y(x)&\approx y(2)+y'(2)(x-2)=1+\frac{1}{2}(x-2)
In particular, y(2.1)&\approx y(2)+y'(2)(2.1-2)=1+\frac{1}{2}(.1)=\boxed{1.05}
The quadratic approximation to y(x) at x=2 is y(x)&\approx y(2)+y'(2)(x-2)+\frac{1}{2} y''(2)(x-2)^2
&=1+\frac{1}{2}(x-2)-\frac{1}{6}(x-2)^2
In particular, y(2.1)&\approx y(2)+y'(2)(2.1-2)+\frac{1}{2} y''(2)(2.1-2)^2
&=1+\frac{1}{2}(.1)-\frac{1}{6}(.1)^2=\boxed{1.0483}
At x=2, y=1 and y'=\frac{1}{2}. So the tangent line passes through (2,1) and has slope \frac{1}{2}. At x=2, y''=-\frac{1}{3}, so the graph y=f(x) (locally!) looks like a parabola pointing down near x=2. This gives the graph fragment below.
Alternatively, we could observe that, near x=2, y(x) will be quite close to its quadratic approximation, 1+\frac{1}{2}(x-2)-\frac{1}{6}(x-2)^2.

statement.p:
The equation x^4+y+xy^4=1 defines y implicitly as a function of x near the point x=-1, y=1.
Use the tangent line approximation at the given point to estimate the value of y when x=-0.9.
Use the quadratic approximation at the given point to get another estimate of y when x=-0.9.
Make a sketch showing how the curve relates to the tangent line at the given point.

solution.p:
y is a function of x that obeys
1&=x^4+y(x)+xy(x)^4
By implicit differentiation (and then subbing in x=-1, y(-1)=1) 0&=4x^3+y'(x)+y(x)^4+4xy(x)^3y'(x)
0&= -4+y'(-1)+1-4y'(-1)
-1&= y'(-1)
Differentiating with respect to x a second time and then subbing in x=-1, y(-1)=1, and y'(-1)=-1: 0&=12x^2+y''(x)+4y(x)^3y'(x)+4y(x)^3y'(x)+12xy(x)^2y'(x)^2
\amp\hskip3in+4xy(x)^3y''(x)
0&= 12+y''(-1)-4-4-12-4y''(-1)
-8&= 3y''(-1)
y''(-1)&=-\frac{8}{3}
The tangent line approximation to y(x) at x=-1 is
y(x)&\approx y(-1)+y'(-1)(x+1)=1-(x+1)=-x
In particular, y(-0.9)&\approx 0.9
The quadratic approximation to y(x) at x=-1 is
y(x)&\approx y(-1)+y'(-1)(x+1)+\frac{1}{2} y''(-1)(x+1)^2
&=1-(x+1)-\frac{4}{3}(x+1)^2
In particular, y(-0.9)&\approx 1-(.1)-\frac{4}{3}(.1)^2\approx{0.8867}
At x=-1, the slope of the curve is y'(-1)=-1. Its tangent line is falling at 45^\circ. At x=-1, y''(-1)=-\frac{8}{3}, so the slope of the curve is decreasing as x passes through -1. Zoomed in very close, the curve looks like a parabola opening downwards. This gives the figure

statement.p: Given that \log 10\approx 2.30259, estimate \log 10.3 using a suitable tangent line approximation. Give an upper and lower bound for the error in your approximation by using a suitable error estimate.

Consider f(x)=e^{e^x}.
Give the linear approximation for f near x=0 (call this L(x)).
Give the quadratic approximation for f near x=0 (call this Q(x)).
Prove that L(x) \lt Q(x) \lt f(x) for all x \gt 0.
Find an interval of length at most 0.01 that is guaranteed to contain the number e^{0.1}.

hint.p: For (c), you can write f(x) as the sum of Q(x) and its error term.
For (d), you can use the linear approximation of e^x centred at 0, with its error term when x=0.1.

answer.p: (c) Since ex^2 \gt 0 for all x \gt 0, L(x) \lt Q(x) for all x \gt 0.

From the error formula, we know that
f(x)&=f(0)+f'(0)x+\half f''(0)x^2 +\dfrac{1}{3!}f'''(c)x^{3}
&=Q(x)+\frac{1}{6}\left(e^c+3e^{2c}+e^{3c}\right)e^{e^c}x^3
for some c between 0 and x. Since \frac{1}{6}\left(e^c+3e^{2c}+e^{3c}\right)e^{e^c} is positive for any c, for all x \gt 0, \frac{1}{6}\left(e^c+3e^{2c}+e^{3c}\right)e^{e^c}x^3 \gt 0, so Q(x) \lt f(x).

solution.p:
We begin by finding the values of the derivatives of f at x=0. We can use the chain rule, or the formula we found in Question, Section.
f(x)&=e^{e^x}&f(0)&=e
f'(x)&=e^xe^{e^x}&f'(0)&=e
f''(x)&=\left(e^x+e^{2x}\right)e^{e^x}&f''(0)&=2e
f'''(x)&=\left(e^x+3e^{2x}+e^{3x}\right)e^{e^x}
(c) Since ex^2 \gt 0 for all x \gt 0, L(x) \lt Q(x) for all x \gt 0.

f(x)&=f(0)+f'(0)x+\half f''(0)x^2 +\dfrac{1}{3!}f'''(c)x^{3}
&=Q(x)+\frac{1}{6}\left(e^c+3e^{2c}+e^{3c}\right)e^{e^c}x^3
for some c between 0 and x. Since \frac{1}{6}\left(e^c+3e^{2c}+e^{3c}\right)e^{e^c} is positive for any c, for all x \gt 0, \frac{1}{6}\left(e^c+3e^{2c}+e^{3c}\right)e^{e^c}x^3 \gt 0, so Q(x) \lt f(x).
